description: Composite numbers for which sum of EulerPhi and Divisor-Sum is an integer multiple of the number of divisors.
comments: Makowski proved that phi(n)+Sigma[n] = nd[n] iff n is a prime (see in Sivaramakrishnan,Chapter I, page 8, Theorem 3) In more general case k differs from n.
references: Sivaramakrishnan,R.(1989):Classical Theory of Arithmetical Functions Marcel Dekker,Inc., New York-Basel.
formula: Composite integer solutions of Phi[x]+Sigma[x] = kd[x] or A000203(n)+A000010(n) = k*A000005(n), where k is integer.
example: It is true for all primes and some composites. n = 78, 8 divisors, Sigma = 168, Phi = 24, 168+24 = 192 = 8*24
mathematica: Select[Range[184], ! PrimeQ[#] && Divisible[(DivisorSigma[1, #] + EulerPhi[#]), DivisorSigma[0, #]] &] (* _Jayanta Basu_, Jul 12 2013 *)
author: _Labos Elemer_, Jun 27 2000
